data.name: Saint Petersburg Paradox Model
data.description:
The [Saint Petersburg Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Petersburg_paradox) is a relatively famous example of the divergence between mathematical models and human "rationality".

In few words, assume that you can go on with a bet that works this way: you toss a coin as long as you don't get tails and at each new launch you double the prize which starts from the value of 2.

You will then have a lottery worth (1st toss) `1/2` (chances) `* 2` (prize) `+` (2nd toss) `1/4` (chances) `* 4` (prize) + `1/8` (chances) `* 8` (prize), etc.

It easy to spot that this succession will go up to infinite, assuming that the lottery can pay any sum of money, thus the ticket that is ideally convenient to pay for it will be anything short of infinite (which can be infinite itself).

No player would pay, in reality, much more than something in the range of `20` - `25` units of the same currency of the prize.

Among all the hypotesis, I would gladly go with the work of Tversky & Kahneman and attribute this poor "rationality" to how humans devaluate chances the further they get.

To simplify, let's say that a given player will consider fully the chances of a full toss (which then still values as 1), then it will start to decrease them as unlikely by a given probability weight factor at each successive toss, in a multiplicative way.

So, if the the factor is, say, `0.5`, the first toss will be still worth `1`, the second will be worth `0.5`, the third `0.25`, the fourth `0.125` and so on.

Your goal is to write a function that will compute the perceived value of such a lottery, given such a probability weight factor and the number of steps that are deemed of interest to the player.
